title: Does COVID mess with your DNA?

multiple-choice.question: What is long COVID defined as, according to some researchers?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition that occurs within 2 weeks of COVID-19 infection.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition that occurs between 4 weeks and 3 months following COVID-19 infection.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition that occurs within 4 weeks of COVID-19 infection.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition that occurs more than 3 months after COVID-19 infection.

multiple-choice.question: What is the science of epigenetics based on?

options.label: A
options.text: The changing sequence of DNA.

options.label: B
options.text: The modification of gene expression through environmental factors.

options.label: C
options.text: The marking up of genes with tags that tell the cell's machinery to use that gene more or less often.

options.label: D
options.text: The inheritance of traits from parents.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what might the virus that causes COVID-19 do to epigenetic signals in our cells?

options.label: A
options.text: It might move genetic sticky notes itself.

options.label: B
options.text: It might have no effect on epigenetic signals.

options.label: C
options.text: It might produce more or less of the products of certain genes to make infection less severe.

options.label: D
options.text: It might produce more of the products of the products of certain genes to make infection more severe.

multiple-choice.question: What did a research group based in Sweden study in their 2022 paper published in Clinical Epigenetics?

options.label: A
options.text: Gene expression in the lungs of patients with long COVID.

options.label: B
options.text: Histamine signaling in the brains of patients with long COVID.

options.label: C
options.text: DNA methylation in the blood cells of patients with long COVID.

options.label: D
options.text: ACE2 protein levels in the blood of patients with long COVID.

multiple-choice.question: What did the Swedish research group find in their study of DNA methylation in patients with long COVID?

options.label: A
options.text: No differences in methylation between patients with long COVID and those in remission.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in methylation in patients with long COVID.

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in methylation in patients with long COVID.

options.label: D
options.text: Several genes and groups of genes with changes in their methylation after infection.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential explanations for the increase in cardiovascular events following COVID-19, according to the US-based research group?

options.label: A
options.text: The virus directly causes cardiovascular disease.

options.label: B
options.text: The pattern of gene expression found in their study could help to explain the increase in cardiovascular events.

options.label: C
options.text: The increase in cardiovascular events is due to other factors, not related to COVID-19.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no clear explanation for the increase in cardiovascular events.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what might contribute to inflammation occurring in long COVID?

options.label: A
options.text: The production of more or less of the products of certain genes to make infection less severe.

options.label: B
options.text: The development of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of self-antibodies floating around in patients with long COVID.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential connections between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of similar epigenetic changes in patients with long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome.

options.label: B
options.text: The development of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 virus in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome.

options.label: C
options.text: The increase in cardiovascular events in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no connection between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the study of epigenetic changes in patients with long COVID, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help us understand the underlying causes of long COVID.

options.label: B
options.text: It can help us develop new treatments for long COVID.

options.label: C
options.text: It can help us identify patients at risk of developing long COVID.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: Who are the people that make the SciShow videos possible, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The researchers who study epigenetic changes in patients with long COVID.

options.label: B
options.text: The patients who participate in the studies.

options.label: C
options.text: The people who support SciShow on Patreon.

options.label: D
options.text: The people who watch the SciShow videos.

title: Can alligators survive this apex predator? - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: What is the apex predator in the Everglades ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: Alligators

options.label: B
options.text: Burmese pythons

options.label: C
options.text: Wild boar

options.label: D
options.text: Brazilian peppertrees

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the impact of the exotic pet trade on the Everglades ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: It had no significant impact

options.label: B
options.text: It introduced new species that helped balance the ecosystem

options.label: C
options.text: It led to a 90% decrease in some local mammal populations

options.label: D
options.text: It increased the alligator population

multiple-choice.question: How do alligators contribute to the Everglades ecosystem during the wet season?

options.label: A
options.text: They help to drain the swamp

options.label: B
options.text: They dig holes that become essential watering holes and firebreaks

options.label: C
options.text: They block the sun with their bodies

options.label: D
options.text: They eat invasive species

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why the alligator population has declined in recent years?

options.label: A
options.text: Overhunting by humans

options.label: B
options.text: Competition from other predators

options.label: C
options.text: Decrease in food supply due to invasive species

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What was the main argument made by Marjory Stoneman Douglas in her book about the Everglades?

options.label: A
options.text: That the Everglades should be drained and turned into farmland

options.label: B
options.text: That the alligators are a threat to the ecosystem

options.label: C
options.text: That the alligators are vital to sustaining the ecosystem

options.label: D
options.text: That the Everglades should be protected as a national park

multiple-choice.question: What is a proposed method to control the invasive species in the Everglades?

options.label: A
options.text: Releasing more foreign fauna to balance the scales

options.label: B
options.text: Hunting the invaders down

options.label: C
options.text: Planting non-native trees to block out the sun

options.label: D
options.text: Clogging the rivers with water hyacinths

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the Burmese python population explosion in the Everglades?

options.label: A
options.text: A 90% increase in local mammal populations

options.label: B
options.text: A 90% decrease in some local mammal populations

options.label: C
options.text: A 50% increase in alligator populations

options.label: D
options.text: A 50% decrease in the python population

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of ecotones in the Everglades ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They are areas where the freshwater prairies meet the mangrove forests

options.label: B
options.text: They are areas where the rocky pinelands meet the freshwater prairies

options.label: C
options.text: They are transition areas between habitats that connect the region's freshwater prairies, rocky pinelands, mangrove forests, and more

options.label: D
options.text: They are areas where the alligators live

multiple-choice.question: What makes the Everglades a unique and precious ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: Its high biodiversity

options.label: B
options.text: Its subtropical climate

options.label: C
options.text: Its location

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge facing the Everglades ecosystem today?

options.label: A
options.text: Overhunting by humans

options.label: B
options.text: Competition from other predators

options.label: C
options.text: Decrease in food supply due to invasive species

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Spanish colonizers on the Everglades ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They introduced new species that helped balance the ecosystem

options.label: B
options.text: They had no significant impact

options.label: C
options.text: They introduced wild boar that devoured alligator eggs and spread European parasites to local panthers

options.label: D
options.text: They drained the swamp and turned it into farmland

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the government and business officials' efforts to turn the Everglades into farmland?

options.label: A
options.text: The alligator population increased

options.label: B
options.text: The Everglades became a more diverse ecosystem

options.label: C
options.text: The canals helped to drain the swamp and the non-native trees crowded out the plants local birds relied on for food and shelter

options.label: D
options.text: The Everglades became a national park

title: Which is better for you: "Real" meat or "fake" meat? - Carolyn Beans

options.label: C
options.text: Nearly three-quarters

options.label: D

options.text: Economic factors

options.label: A

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are highly processed and high in sodium

options.label: D
options.text: They are expensive and hard to find

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential drawback of lab-grown meat?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It is a highly processed product

options.label: D
options.text: It is a natural product

options.label: B

options.text: The environmental impact of the farmed meats industry will increase

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Consume more farmed meat

options.label: B
options.text: Consume more plant-based meat alternatives

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why did Megalodon go extinct? - Jack Cooper and Catalina Pimiento

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial conclusion of the Danish scientist regarding the mysterious stones prized for their supposed medicinal powers?

options.label: A
options.text: They were serpent tongues.

options.label: B
options.text: They were fossilized teeth of a prehistoric shark species.

options.label: C
options.text: They were meteorites.

options.label: D
options.text: They were human teeth.

multiple-choice.question: What characteristic of megalodons made their skeletons difficult to find?

options.label: A
options.text: They were made of bone.

options.label: B
options.text: They were cartilaginous.

options.label: C
options.text: They were fossilized.

options.label: D
options.text: They were buried under the ocean.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the growth and development of megalodons based on the presence of small teeth in fossil sites?

options.label: A
options.text: They grew rapidly and reached adulthood quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: They had a slow growth rate and took a long time to reach adulthood.

options.label: C
options.text: They likely grew up in sheltered and food-packed shallow waters before becoming adult marine hunters.

options.label: D
options.text: They were solitary animals and did not interact with each other.

multiple-choice.question: How did scientists estimate the length of megalodons?

options.label: A
options.text: By measuring their vertebrae.

options.label: B
options.text: By comparing their teeth to those of great white sharks.

options.label: C
options.text: By analyzing their fossilized bones.

options.label: D
options.text: By observing their behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What were the contributing factors to the extinction of megalodons?

options.label: A
options.text: The cooling of the global climate.

options.label: B
options.text: The formation of glaciers.

options.label: C
options.text: The drop in sea level.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What was a consequence of the extinction of megalodons on the marine ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: The increase in size of marine mammals.

options.label: B
options.text: The decrease in size of marine mammals.

options.label: C
options.text: The disruption of nutrient transport between different ecosystems.

options.label: D
options.text: The increase in the number of predators.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the behavior of megalodons based on their fossilized bones?

options.label: A
options.text: They were solitary animals and did not interact with each other.

options.label: B
options.text: They were ambush predators and did not chase their prey.

options.label: C
options.text: They were active predators and pursued their prey.

options.label: D
options.text: They were likely active predators that pursued their prey, as evidenced by their powerful jaws and bite marks on fossilized bones.

multiple-choice.question: What is a conservation concern related to the extinction of megalodons?

options.label: A
options.text: The decline of apex predators can destabilize entire ecosystems.

options.label: B
options.text: The increase in the number of predators can lead to overhunting.

options.label: C
options.text: The decrease in the number of predators can lead to an increase in prey populations.

options.label: D
options.text: The extinction of megalodons had no impact on the ecosystem.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the relationship between megalodons and their prey based on the analysis of their teeth?

options.label: A
options.text: They were scavengers and did not hunt their prey.

options.label: B
options.text: They were ambush predators and did not chase their prey.

options.label: C
options.text: They were active predators and pursued their prey.

options.label: D
options.text: They ate both large prey species and other predators, as evidenced by the presence of nitrogen isotopes in their teeth.

multiple-choice.question: What is a testament to ecological interdependence and millions of years of evolution based on the fossil record of megalodons?

options.label: A
options.text: The extinction of megalodons had no impact on the ecosystem.

options.label: B
options.text: The decline of apex predators can destabilize entire ecosystems.

options.label: C
options.text: The increase in size of marine mammals after the extinction of megalodons.

options.label: D
options.text: The fossil record of megalodons is a testament to ecological interdependence and millions of years of evolution, highlighting the complex relationships between species and their environments.
